TQFTs and height n

Jun 22, 2019

I’d like to explore the topic brought up at the end of the previous post. The existence of a twisting map , conjecturally described by algebraic K-theory, led to us suggesting that if one has a map , it might be possible to define an -dimensional TQFT with gauge group (where is finite). This post is going to be uncompromisingly speculative and lacking in details.

What we’d like is a symmetric monoidal -category whose -morphisms for are height data. For instance, the objects in should be height data, the -morphisms should be height zero data (e.g., differential graded -vector spaces), and the -morphisms should be bimodule homomorphisms. Each finite group should define an associated gauge theory ; this should be related by some sort of algebraic K-theory construction to 2-dimensional Chern-Simons theory , which sends to . Since , we might expect . If is finite, then this is a finite -algebra, so we might want the objects of to be --algebras.

Great: we’ve got a category whose objects are --algebras (with symmetric monoidal structure given by the tensor product of -algebras), and whose morphisms are supposed to be -vector spaces. So how are morphisms defined? A morphism between --algebras and can be defined as an -bimodule , where the base change takes place along the map . For instance, if is a symmetric monoidal functor, then is the center , taken in differential graded -vector spaces. If , then is the 2-periodic group ring , so is ; this is an implementation of Hopkins-Kuhn-Ravenel character theory at height 1.

How do we define in general? Motivated by the appearance of HKR character theory, we might attempt to define via transchromatic character theory. For , we might expect the -morphisms of to admit the structure of a -module, where is the universal -algebra over which the universal height spectral deformation splits as , where is connected. (We’ve fixed a perfect field and a formal group of height over .)

Let’s contemplate this for a moment: as in the height 1 case, if and are objects of , i.e., --algebras, then we can define a morphism between and to be an -algebra in -bimodules. If we now have two such and , we’d like a 2-morphism to be an algebra object in bimodules over some base-change of and to . However, there is no map , but we have the next best thing: in the linked post, we defined a map , where is a -divisible group over whose connected-etale sequence splits and whose connected component has height . By the universal property of , there is an -algebra map , so by composing with the map which lands in the height Lubin-Tate theory , we obtain -algebras and in -bimodules from and ; these guys are height .

We might as well do away with character theory in this story, and just define a morphism between and in to be an -algebra in -bimodules. (Note that this doesn’t recover our construction of in the case , since in this case is not .) Iterating the construction from our linked post, we obtain a tower

of -algebras, where is a height Lubin-Tate theory, is what we denoted , and . Naturally, we expect an -morphism for between -morphisms and in would be an -algebra in -bimodules.

OK, so: does this make sense? Is even well-defined? Is it a symmetric monoidal -category? If so, we would like to say that if is a finite group, then -equivariant E-theory (whose definition I only know when is finite abelian, namely as being described by ) is fully dualizable in this weird -category , and so defines a TQFT . More generally, if is a -finite -truncated space, then the tempered cohomology -ring should be fully dualizable in , and hence should define a TQFT .
